Rand Paul pitching in to help Republican candidates

With election near, Kentucky Sen. Rand Paul buying ads as part of effort to boost Republican candidates

Rand Paul pitching in to help Republican candidates

Politics

James R. Carroll, The Courier-Journal 6:14 p.m. EDT October 28, 2014

Sen. Rand Paul of Kentucky.(Photo: The Associated Press)

Tags

  • Mitch McConnell
  • Pat Roberts
  • Rand Paul
  • Republican Party
9 CONNECT 4 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

WASHINGTON - With balloting less than a week away, Kentucky Sen. Rand Paul is expanding his assistance to Republican candidates with television ads in Kentucky and other states.

Already a near-constant presence on the campaign trail this year, Paul has decided to use the resources of his political action committee, RANDPAC, to give an additional boost to GOP Senate candidates.

RANDPAC went up with an ad in Kansas Tuesday to help incumbent Sen. Pat Roberts, who is in a tight race with independent challenger Greg Orman. RANDPAC Executive Director Doug Stafford said the ad buy totaled six figures.

"Pat Roberts was one of a few true conservative senators who stood with Rand Paul and said stop sending taxpayers' money to countries where radicals storm our embassies, burn our flag and kill our diplomats," the ad says in part. "Pat Roberts - fighting for our American home, by bringing our tax dollars home."

Paul's operation is preparing to run an ad in Kentucky on behalf of Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., who is battling Democratic opponent Alison Lundergan Grimes.

We have not yet obtained details on what that ad will say or how large a buy RANDPAC is making in the commonwealth.

RELATED: Rand Paul says that in foreign policy, "America cannot disengage from the world"

RELATED: TIME magazine puts Paul on its cover

RELATED: Paul plans strategy session 8 days after the election

RANDPAC also has plans to run ads for Republican Senate candidates in North Carolina and - 2016 alert - New Hampshire and Iowa.

Paul, of course, is a potential 2016 GOP presidential candidate. The earliest contests are in New Hampshire and Iowa.

Smart move to do these spots for other Republicans, says Chris Cillizza at The Washington Post.

"None of the ad buys are massive or are likely to make any real impact in the final days of these races," Cillizza writes. "But the point isn't really to sway persuadable voters. It's to (a) show that Rand is a team player and (b) build up some chits among people either in the Senate or, maybe, coming to the Senate in the next week or so."

"...It's far from the first smart thing Paul has done as he tries to make sure the establishment knows he doesn't have horns and a tail."
